vocabulary.trait: Extract a reply or action; provoke.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The interviewer asked probing questions to elicit detailed responses.
The researcher designed the experiment to elicit specific behaviors from the participants.
vocabulary.synonyms: draw out, evoke, extract, prompt, provoke

vocabulary.trait: Possessing great knowledge, typically from study or research.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The erudite scholar had mastered several ancient languages.
Her erudite commentary on the text impressed even the most skeptical critics.

vocabulary.trait: Fertile or highly productive.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The fecund soil produced abundant crops year after year.
She has a fecund imagination that generates countless creative ideas.

vocabulary.trait: Weak; deficient in strength.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The patient's voice became increasingly feeble as his illness progressed.
Their feeble attempts to solve the crisis were ineffective.

vocabulary.trait:
Well-suited or apt
; Causing delight or satisfaction.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The speaker made a felicitous choice of words for the occasion.
The timing of their arrival was particularly felicitous.

vocabulary.trait: Refrain or abstain from doing something.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) to Positive (+ve)
Neutral: Simply describing restraint
Positive: When showing remarkable self-control
vocabulary.example:
Please forbear from making comments until the end of the presentation.
He had to forbear his impulse to correct every minor error.
vocabulary.synonyms: refrain, abstain, desist, resist, hold back

vocabulary.trait: Lacking clear planning, order, or direction.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The project failed due to their haphazard approach to management.
The books were arranged in a haphazard manner on the shelves.

vocabulary.trait: A mixture or assortment of different things.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) to Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing an eclectic mix
Negative: When implying disorganization
vocabulary.example:
The museum collection was a hodgepodge of artifacts from various historical periods.
The report was a hodgepodge of unrelated facts and opinions.

vocabulary.trait: Obstruct or hinder progress.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The heavy traffic impeded our journey to the airport.
Bureaucratic procedures often impede innovation in large organizations.

vocabulary.trait: Rash or hasty in action or decision.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His impetuous decision to quit his job without another lined up caused financial strain.
The general's impetuous attack resulted in unnecessary casualties.

vocabulary.trait: Easily angered or irritated.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The irascible professor often lost his temper during class discussions.
Lack of sleep made her increasingly irascible throughout the day.

vocabulary.trait: Motivated primarily by a desire for monetary or material gain.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His decision to change companies was purely mercenary, based solely on the higher salary offered.
They criticized the artist for taking a mercenary approach to his work.

vocabulary.trait: Exhibiting great care to detail.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The watchmaker was meticulous in assembling the tiny components.
Her meticulous research uncovered previously overlooked evidence.

vocabulary.trait: Biting or sharply critical in thought or expression.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) to Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When used for incisive critique
Negative: When excessively harsh or cutting
vocabulary.example:
The reviewer was known for his mordant critiques of pretentious films.
Her mordant wit made her both admired and feared at social gatherings.

vocabulary.trait: Surpass or do better than.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) to Positive (+ve) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The company's performance continues to outstrip that of its competitors.
Demand for the new product has outstripped supply.

vocabulary.trait: Uncertain and likely to cause danger.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The climbers were in a precarious position on the cliff face.
The country's economy remains in a precarious state following the recession.

vocabulary.trait: Unusual in an endearing or peculiar way.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) to Positive (+ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing something simply unusual
Positive: When the unusual quality is charming
vocabulary.example:
The film director is known for his quirky approach to storytelling.
She has a quirky sense of humor that makes her popular at parties.

vocabulary.trait: Reject or refute.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) to Negative (–ve) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The politician was quick to repudiate the false accusations.
The company repudiated its previous position on environmental policies.

vocabulary.trait: Skill in handling difficult situations without causing offense.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She showed great tact in dealing with the sensitive issue.
Diplomatic negotiations require tact and finesse.

vocabulary.trait: Lacking significance or importance.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Don't waste time on trifling matters when there are serious issues to address.
The error was trifling and had no effect on the outcome.

vocabulary.trait: Full of conflict or chaos.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The country experienced a turbulent period of political upheaval.
The aircraft encountered turbulent conditions during the flight.

vocabulary.trait: Quickness and keenness in understanding and judgment.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Her business acumen helped the company thrive during economic downturn.
The detective's acumen allowed him to solve cases that baffled others.

vocabulary.trait: The direct opposite or contrast.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Their parenting styles are the antithesis of each other—one strict, one permissive.
Her calm demeanor was the antithesis of her brother's excitable nature.

vocabulary.trait: Attribute or credit something to a particular cause or source.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Critics ascribe the painting's uniqueness to the artist's unconventional techniques.
He ascribed his success to hard work and determination.

vocabulary.trait: Confused, bewildered, or perplexed.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The elderly man looked befuddled by the complex technology.
After reading the convoluted instructions, I was completely befuddled.

vocabulary.trait: Intentionally avoid or abstain from.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She eschewed social media to focus on her mental health.
Many monks eschew material possessions in pursuit of spiritual enlightenment.

vocabulary.trait: Understood by few or a small group of people; specialized or obscure.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The professor's lecture was filled with esoteric terminology only comprehensible to experts.
He collects esoteric musical instruments from around the world.

vocabulary.trait: Indirect or not straightforward; avoiding confrontation.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The politician gave evasive answers to direct questions.
Her evasive behavior made me suspect she was hiding something.

vocabulary.trait: Clear from blame or guilt.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The new evidence exculpated the wrongfully convicted man.
Her testimony helped exculpate her colleague from allegations of misconduct.

vocabulary.trait: Accelerate or speed up a process or action.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The manager implemented new software to expedite customer service.
We need to expedite the shipping process to meet the deadline.

vocabulary.trait: Showing great care and attention to detail; hard to please.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Positive: When referring to thoroughness and meticulousness.
Negative: When indicating excessive pickiness or fussiness.
vocabulary.example:
The fastidious chef inspected every plate before it left the kitchen.
His fastidious nature made him difficult to work with.

vocabulary.trait: Pretend or simulate, especially feelings or symptoms.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
She had to feign interest in his boring stories.
The student feigned illness to avoid taking the test.

vocabulary.trait: Sneaky or secretive, especially due to guilt or dubious motives.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
He cast furtive glances around before slipping the note under her door.
The suspicious behavior and furtive movements made the security guard take notice.

vocabulary.trait: Obstruct or hinder progress.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Bad weather hampered the rescue efforts.
Budget cuts seriously hampered their ability to complete the project.

vocabulary.trait: Completely necessary; essential.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She quickly became an indispensable member of our team.
Clean water is indispensable for human survival.

vocabulary.trait: Express deep sorrow or regret.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The widow lamented the loss of her husband.
Environmental activists lament the destruction of rainforests.

vocabulary.trait: Short-sighted; lacking creativity or foresight.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The company's myopic focus on quarterly profits damaged its long-term sustainability.
His myopic view prevented him from seeing the broader implications.

vocabulary.trait: Appearing casually calm or indifferent.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Positive: When indicating composure under pressure.
Negative: When suggesting inappropriate indifference.
vocabulary.example:
Despite the pressure, she remained nonchalant during the negotiations.
His nonchalant attitude toward safety regulations concerned his supervisors.

vocabulary.trait: Prejudiced or biased toward one side; showing favoritism.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) when referring to bias
Neutral (0) when referring to incompleteness
vocabulary.example:
The referee was accused of being partial to the home team.
We only have partial information about what happened.

vocabulary.trait: Deep in thought, often with a touch of sadness or wistfulness.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She looked pensive as she gazed out the window at the rain.
His pensive mood followed him throughout the day after receiving the news.

vocabulary.trait: Indicate or warn that something, often unpleasant, is going to happen.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) with negative connotation
vocabulary.example:
Dark clouds portend a coming storm.
The market fluctuations portend economic instability.

vocabulary.trait: Narrow in perspective; not sophisticated; relating to provinces.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) when referring to narrowness
Neutral (0) when referring to geographic origin
vocabulary.example:
His provincial attitudes made it difficult for him to adapt to the cosmopolitan city.
The museum houses a collection of provincial French art.

vocabulary.trait: Basic or elementary; in the earliest stages of development.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) with slight negative connotation
vocabulary.example:
The tribe had only rudimentary tools at their disposal.
She has a rudimentary understanding of computer programming.

vocabulary.trait: Beneficial, especially in promoting health or well-being.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The mountain retreat had a salutary effect on her mental health.
The scandal had the salutary effect of exposing corrupt practices in the industry.

vocabulary.trait: Cut off or put an end to abruptly.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) with negative connotation
vocabulary.example:
She decided to sever all ties with her former business partner.
The accident severed his spinal cord, leaving him paralyzed.

vocabulary.trait: Treat with disrespect or neglect; insult.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
He felt slighted when he wasn't invited to the meeting.
She didn't mean to slight her colleague by forgetting to acknowledge his contribution.

vocabulary.trait: Sleepy or drowsy; inducing sleep.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Negative: When referring to undesirable drowsiness or dullness.
vocabulary.example:
The professor's monotonous voice had a somnolent effect on the class.
The medication's somnolent side effects made driving dangerous.

vocabulary.trait: Unaffected by pain or distress; showing no emotion.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Positive: When indicating strength and resilience.
Negative: When suggesting emotional detachment.
vocabulary.example:
She remained stoic throughout the difficult medical procedure.
His stoic response to the tragedy made others wonder if he cared at all.

vocabulary.trait: Replace or take the place of.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Digital technology has largely superseded film photography.
The new regulations supersede all previous guidelines.

vocabulary.trait: Promote or praise energetically.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Positive: When genuinely promoting something of value.
Negative: When overselling or making exaggerated claims.
vocabulary.example:
The company touts its new software as revolutionary.
Critics tout the film as the best of the year.

vocabulary.trait: Decrease in power, size, or intensity.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
His influence in the party began to wane after the scandal.
Public interest in the story has waned over time.

vocabulary.trait: Detest or regard with deep hatred.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
She abhors violence in any form.
Most people abhor the idea of animal cruelty.

vocabulary.trait: Energetic, noisy, and lively.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Positive: When describing healthy enthusiasm or energy.
Negative: When the energy is disruptive or excessive.
vocabulary.example:
The children were boisterous during the birthday party.
His boisterous laughter filled the room.

vocabulary.trait: Honorable and polite, especially toward women.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
He was chivalrous enough to open the door for her.
The knight was known for his chivalrous behavior in battle.

vocabulary.trait: Rude or lacking good manners.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
It would be churlish to refuse such a generous offer.
His churlish behavior at the dinner party embarrassed everyone.

vocabulary.trait: Secretive; avoiding attention, often for illicit purposes.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
They held clandestine meetings to plan the surprise party.
The government uncovered a clandestine operation to smuggle weapons.

vocabulary.trait: Smugly self-satisfied, often without awareness of potential dangers.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
After years of success, the company became complacent and failed to innovate.
We cannot afford to be complacent about climate change.

vocabulary.trait: Large, heavy, slow or complicated and therefore difficult to use or manage.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The old software system was cumbersome and inefficient.
She struggled with the cumbersome equipment during the hike.

vocabulary.trait: Weakening or impairing strength.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
She suffers from a debilitating illness that affects her mobility.
The heat wave had a debilitating effect on the workforce.

vocabulary.trait: Think over or discuss carefully; Intentional, planned, or done on purpose.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
We need to deliberate on this issue before making a decision.
The attack was a deliberate attempt to undermine the peace process.

vocabulary.trait: Amusing in a quirky or unusual way.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The comedian's droll observations about everyday life had the audience laughing.
He has a droll sense of humor that not everyone appreciates.

vocabulary.trait: Deviating from conventional behavior; quirky or unusual in habits or appearance.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The eccentric professor wore mismatched socks and talked to his plants.
The town is known for its eccentric characters and unusual traditions.

vocabulary.trait: Quarrelsome and irritable; unruly or difficult to control.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The fractious meeting ended without any resolution.
The child became fractious when tired and hungry.

vocabulary.trait: Clear, transparent, or easy to understand.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Her limpid explanation made the complex theory understandable.
The lake's limpid waters revealed colorful fish swimming below.

vocabulary.trait: Overly sentimental in a way that seems exaggerated or insincere.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The film's mawkish ending was criticized by reviewers.
She found his mawkish displays of affection embarrassing.

vocabulary.trait: Reverence, respect, or deference shown to an individual or authority.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The courtiers made obeisance to the king as he entered.
Corporate culture often requires obeisance to senior management.

vocabulary.trait: Showy or designed to impress; characterized by vulgar or pretentious display.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Their ostentatious wealth made others uncomfortable.
The palace was decorated in an ostentatious style with gold leaf everywhere.

vocabulary.trait: A perfect cure or solution for all problems or difficulties.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Technology is not a panacea for all educational challenges.
The new policy was presented as a panacea for economic inequality.
vocabulary.synonyms: cure-all, universal remedy, magic bullet, elixir

vocabulary.trait: Done without enthusiasm or effort; carried out with minimal attention or care.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The doctor gave the patient a perfunctory examination.
He offered a perfunctory apology that no one believed was sincere.

vocabulary.trait: Risky and hazardous; full of danger or risk.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The mountain climbers faced perilous conditions in the storm.
Crossing the river during the flood was a perilous undertaking.

vocabulary.trait: Spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Corruption was pervasive throughout the government.
The smell of smoke was pervasive in the building after the fire.

vocabulary.trait: Prevent something from happening or make it impossible.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Her prior commitments preclude her from attending the conference.
The terms of the agreement preclude any further negotiation.
vocabulary.synonyms: prevent, prohibit, rule out, make impossible, hinder

vocabulary.trait: Preference or bias towards something; a natural liking for something.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She has a predilection for spicy food.
His predilection for classical music influenced his career choice.

vocabulary.trait: Very greedy; aggressively and excessively grasping or acquisitive.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The rapacious developer bought up all the land in the area.
Colonial powers were often rapacious in their exploitation of resources.

vocabulary.trait: Take great pleasure or delight in something.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She relished the opportunity to showcase her talents.
He relished the challenge of climbing the mountain.
vocabulary.synonyms: enjoy, savor, appreciate, delight in, love

vocabulary.trait: Using humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to criticize or mock others, particularly in the context of contemporary politics and other topical issues.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The satirical cartoon mocked the government's latest policy.
The novel is a satirical look at modern corporate culture.

vocabulary.trait: Fake; not genuine; something that is not what it appears to be.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The diamond necklace turned out to be a sham.
Their marriage was a sham, arranged only for visa purposes.

vocabulary.trait: Go around or avoid something, especially an issue or obstacle.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The politician tried to skirt the controversial question.
The path skirts the edge of the cliff, offering spectacular views.

vocabulary.trait: Lacking energy; slow and listless.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The economy remained sluggish despite government intervention.
After the large meal, he felt sluggish and wanted to nap.

vocabulary.trait: Marked by simplicity, frugality, and avoidance of luxury and comfort.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The monastery offered only spartan accommodations for visitors.
He lived a spartan lifestyle, owning only what he needed.

vocabulary.trait: Aggressively combative or confrontational; eager to argue or fight.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The truculent customer complained loudly about the service.
His truculent attitude made it difficult to work with him.

vocabulary.trait: Bitter and sharp in language or tone
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The divorce proceedings became increasingly acrimonious as both parties refused to compromise.
Their acrimonious debate left everyone in the room feeling uncomfortable.

vocabulary.trait: Argumentative, threatening, or aggressive
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The belligerent customer demanded to speak to the manager.
His belligerent attitude made it impossible to have a rational conversation.

vocabulary.trait: Kind and charitable, producing good results or benefits
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The beneficent donor contributed millions to cancer research.
Her beneficent actions improved the lives of countless children in need.

vocabulary.trait: Shrewd and cautious
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The canny investor always researched thoroughly before making decisions.
Her canny negotiating skills secured an excellent deal for the company.

vocabulary.trait: Exhibiting an overly casual attitude; unconcerned
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The manager's cavalier attitude toward workplace safety concerned many employees.
He was cavalier about missing the deadline, which frustrated the entire team.

vocabulary.trait: Experiencing nervousness, irritation, or sadness
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
She became distressed when she heard the bad news.
The distressed child couldn't stop crying after losing his favorite toy.

vocabulary.trait: Decreasing steadily in size or quantity
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The company's profits have been dwindling for three consecutive quarters.
The dwindling daylight reminded us that winter was approaching.

vocabulary.trait: Overshadow or surpass
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Her recent achievements eclipsed her earlier failures.
The new smartphone's features eclipse those of its competitors.
vocabulary.antonyms: fall short, underperform, trail, lag behind

vocabulary.trait: Thorough; comprehensive in scope
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The professor had encyclopedic knowledge of ancient civilizations.
Her encyclopedic memory allowed her to recall obscure facts with ease.

vocabulary.trait: Make a situation or condition worse
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His rude comments only exacerbated the tense situation.
Lack of sleep can exacerbate symptoms of anxiety.

vocabulary.trait: Severely irritated or angry
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The teacher became exasperated by the students' constant chatter.
She gave an exasperated sigh when her computer crashed again.

vocabulary.trait: Interchangeable for another item of a similar type
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Currency is fungible because one dollar bill can be exchanged for any other dollar bill.
Unlike unique artwork, basic commodities like oil are fungible.

vocabulary.trait: Lacking creativity; derivative and overused
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The movie relied on hackneyed plot devices that bored the audience.
His speech was full of hackneyed phrases that failed to inspire.

vocabulary.trait: Out of place; lacking harmony
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The casual sneakers looked incongruous with his formal suit.
The modern skyscraper seemed incongruous among the ancient buildings.

vocabulary.trait: Capable of being used in place of each other
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The parts are interchangeable across all models in this product line.
The two terms are often used as if they were interchangeable, but they have subtle differences.

vocabulary.trait: Economical with words; quiet and reserved
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
His laconic response consisted of just a single word.
The laconic detective revealed little about the investigation.

vocabulary.trait: Producing a significant amount of money
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She left academia for a more lucrative position in the private sector.
The contract proved to be extremely lucrative for the small company.

vocabulary.trait:
Possessing great authority
; Exercising authority in an excessive manner
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Positive: When referring to authoritative expertise
Negative: When describing overbearing behavior
vocabulary.example:
The historian produced a magisterial work on the Civil War.
The judge's magisterial attitude alienated everyone in the courtroom.

vocabulary.trait: Involving a heavy burden; challenging or difficult
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The onerous task required hours of tedious work.
The new regulations imposed onerous requirements on small businesses.

vocabulary.trait: Severe criticism or public shame
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The politician faced public opprobrium after the scandal came to light.
His unethical actions earned him the opprobrium of his colleagues.

vocabulary.trait: Extremely frugal or stingy
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The parsimonious businessman refused to donate to charity despite his wealth.
The company's parsimonious approach to employee benefits hurt morale.

vocabulary.trait: Of marginal importance; minor
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She focused on the main issues and ignored peripheral concerns.
His role in the project was peripheral; he contributed very little.

vocabulary.trait: Causing outrage or irritation, often intentionally
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
His provocative comments sparked a heated debate.
The artist's provocative work challenged conventional thinking about beauty.

vocabulary.trait: Reject or give up
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She decided to renounce her citizenship and move abroad permanently.
The leader renounced violence and called for peaceful negotiations.

vocabulary.trait:
(of emotions or actions) Unrestrained and turbulent
; (of weather) Extremely stormy
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
They had a tempestuous relationship marked by frequent arguments.
The ship struggled to navigate through the tempestuous seas.

vocabulary.trait: (of an idea or method) Justifiable and rational
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
After reviewing the evidence, her theory seemed perfectly tenable.
The company's financial position is no longer tenable given the current market conditions.

vocabulary.trait: A violation of a law, rule, or social norm
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The minor transgression was quickly forgiven and forgotten.
His repeated transgressions eventually led to his dismissal from the team.

vocabulary.trait: Refined, sophisticated, and courteous
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The urbane host made everyone feel welcome at the gala.
His urbane manner and witty conversation impressed all the guests.

vocabulary.trait: Appearance or semblance of truth or reality; believability
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The historical novel was praised for its verisimilitude.
The filmmaker strived for verisimilitude in depicting life in ancient Rome.

vocabulary.trait: Impair or corrupt the quality of something
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Errors in the methodology vitiated the study's results.
The scandal vitiated the politician's reputation beyond repair.

vocabulary.trait: A natural liking or connection to a person, thing, or idea; a similarity between two things.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates connection, attraction, or natural compatibility.
vocabulary.example:
She has a strong affinity for classical music.
There's a clear affinity between the two theories.

vocabulary.trait: Showing generosity and concern for the welfare of others.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates selflessness and compassion.
vocabulary.example:
Her altruistic nature led her to volunteer at the homeless shelter.
The businessman made an altruistic donation to the charity.

vocabulary.trait: Overly detailed or ornamental; elaborate in style.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (-ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing artistic style.
Negative: When implying excessive decoration.
vocabulary.example:
The palace featured baroque architecture with intricate details.
His baroque writing style made the simple story difficult to follow.

vocabulary.trait: Overly complex or intricate; characterized by complicated bureaucracy.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Typically implies unnecessary complexity.
vocabulary.example:
The tax code is so byzantine that most people need professional help.
The company's byzantine approval process delayed the project for months.

vocabulary.trait: Weaken or diminish in quality, character, or value; to settle differences by mutual concession.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (-ve) depending on context
Neutral: When referring to finding middle ground.
Negative: When referring to weakening or corrupting something.
vocabulary.example:
They reached a compromise that satisfied both parties.
The leak compromised the security of the database.

vocabulary.trait: Intended to appease or calm someone down; promoting reconciliation.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates desire for peace and resolution.
vocabulary.example:
He made a conciliatory gesture by apologizing first.
Her conciliatory tone helped defuse the tense situation.

vocabulary.trait: Accept or permit; the look of a person's face or expression.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
As a verb (to permit) or noun (facial expression).
vocabulary.example:
The principal would not countenance such behavior in school.
His countenance revealed his disappointment without words.

vocabulary.trait: Hidden or concealed; not openly practiced or acknowledged.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Often implies secrecy with negative intent.
vocabulary.example:
The spy conducted covert operations in the foreign country.
They had a covert agreement that was hidden from management.

vocabulary.trait: Able to be trusted or believed; persuasive.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates reliability and believability.
vocabulary.example:
Her testimony was considered credible by the jury.
The study provided credible evidence for the new theory.

vocabulary.trait: Spread or disperse widely; scattered over a large area.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Describes a physical state or process.
vocabulary.example:
The scent of roses diffused throughout the room.
Light diffused through the frosted glass, creating a soft glow.

vocabulary.trait: Based on or reproducing real events or facts; a film or program presenting facts objectively.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Factual presentation without inherent judgment.
vocabulary.example:
The documentary about climate change won several awards.
She collected documentary evidence of the historical event.

vocabulary.trait: Thorough and comprehensive; including all possibilities.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates thoroughness and completeness.
vocabulary.example:
The researchers conducted an exhaustive study on the subject.
The book provides an exhaustive analysis of medieval literature.

vocabulary.trait: Intensely exciting; making one feel very happy, animated, or elated.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates strong positive emotional response.
vocabulary.example:
The roller coaster ride was exhilarating.
The team found the victory absolutely exhilarating.

vocabulary.trait: Lacking relevance; unnecessary or unrelated to the subject.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Implies irrelevance or superfluousness.
vocabulary.example:
Please avoid adding extraneous details to your report.
The professor asked them to remove all extraneous information from their presentations.

vocabulary.trait: Intense enthusiasm toward something; passionate intensity.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Indicates strong passion that can be constructive or excessive.
vocabulary.example:
She approached her new project with fervor.
Religious fervor motivated the pilgrims to make the difficult journey.

vocabulary.trait: Incapable of resulting in anything worthwhile; pointless or useless.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Indicates lack of effectiveness or purpose.
vocabulary.example:
Their attempts to repair the damaged engine proved futile.
It seemed futile to argue with someone so stubborn.

vocabulary.trait: Unreal or based on illusion; deceptive in nature.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Implies deception or false appearance.
vocabulary.example:
The economic stability proved to be illusory.
Their hope for immediate success was illusory.

vocabulary.trait: Likely to cause resentment or envy; unfair or prejudiced against someone or something.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Indicates unfairness or actions causing ill will.
vocabulary.example:
The manager's invidious treatment of certain employees led to workplace tension.
Making invidious comparisons between siblings can damage their relationship.

vocabulary.trait: Sluggish; tired or lacking energy; pathologically drowsy.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Indicates undesirable lack of energy or motivation.
vocabulary.example:
After the large meal, everyone felt lethargic.
The humid weather made the workers lethargic and unproductive.

vocabulary.trait: Symbolic rather than literal; containing or using metaphors.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Describes figurative rather than literal language.
vocabulary.example:
The poem is full of metaphorical language about life's journey.
Her metaphorical description of depression as a heavy blanket was powerful.

vocabulary.trait: To imitate or copy someone or something, often in an amusing way.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (-ve) depending on context
Can be playful or mocking.
vocabulary.example:
The parrot can mimic human speech with surprising accuracy.
The comedian's ability to mimic the president drew laughter from the audience.

vocabulary.trait: Having a spiritual or divine quality; indicating the presence of divinity.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates transcendent or spiritual quality.
vocabulary.example:
The ancient temple had a numinous atmosphere.
Many describe a numinous feeling when witnessing natural wonders like the northern lights.

vocabulary.trait: Not clearly expressed or understood; making something unclear and vague; not well-known.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Can indicate lack of clarity or simply lack of fame.
vocabulary.example:
The professor's explanation was too obscure for the students to understand.
She specializes in translating obscure medieval texts.

vocabulary.trait: Open and observable; not hidden or secret.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Describes visibility without inherent judgment.
vocabulary.example:
The government made an overt attempt to improve foreign relations.
There was overt hostility between the two competing teams.

vocabulary.trait: Transparently clear in meaning or style; (of a body of water or substance) transparent and clear.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates desirable clarity and transparency.
vocabulary.example:
Her pellucid explanation made the complex concept easy to understand.
The pellucid waters of the Caribbean revealed colorful coral reefs below.

vocabulary.trait: Make something continue for an indefinite time; preserve from extinction or oblivion.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (-ve) depending on context
Can be positive when preserving good things, negative when continuing problems.
vocabulary.example:
These policies perpetuate inequality in education.
The organization works to perpetuate traditional craftsmanship.

vocabulary.trait: Based on clear thought or reason; logical and sensible.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates desirable logical thinking.
vocabulary.example:
The committee made a rational decision based on the available data.
In times of crisis, it's important to remain rational.

vocabulary.trait: Harshly or bitterly critical; vitriolic; severe.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Indicates harsh or severe criticism.
vocabulary.example:
The critic wrote a scathing review of the play.
Her scathing remarks about the proposal silenced the room.

vocabulary.trait: Delicate or slight; not obvious or direct; requiring careful attention.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
Indicates refinement or nuance.
vocabulary.example:
There was a subtle difference between the two paint colors.
The film contains subtle references to classical literature.

vocabulary.trait: Existing, occurring, or located on the surface; not profound or thorough; concerned only with what is obvious.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (-ve)
Indicates lack of depth or thoroughness.
vocabulary.example:
The wound was fortunately superficial and required no stitches.
He only had a superficial understanding of the complex issue.

vocabulary.trait: To agree or consent quietly without protest or enthusiasm.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Can be positive when showing reasonable accommodation or negative when suggesting passive compliance.
vocabulary.example:
The committee acquiesced to the CEO's demands to avoid conflict.
After much debate, she finally acquiesced to her friend's suggestion.

vocabulary.trait: Skillful, clever, or dexterous in using the hands or mind.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates competence and skill.
vocabulary.example:
The adroit surgeon completed the complex procedure flawlessly.
She was adroit at navigating office politics.

vocabulary.trait: To change or modify for the better; to improve by alteration.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
Generally positive when improving something, neutral when simply making changes.
vocabulary.example:
Congress voted to amend the legislation to address public concerns.
The author amended her manuscript based on editor feedback.

vocabulary.trait: Strong hostility or ill will; animosity or enmity.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates hostility and negative emotions.
vocabulary.example:
There was clear animus between the two political candidates during the debate.
His animus toward his former employer was evident in his scathing remarks.

vocabulary.trait: A person who offers a defense or justification for something controversial.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve)
Often carries negative connotations suggesting blind defense of problematic positions.
vocabulary.example:
He has become an apologist for the company's controversial environmental policies.
She is known as an apologist for classical education methods.

vocabulary.trait: Severe or harsh in manner, style, or character; sharp or bitter.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0)
Generally negative when describing personality, can be neutral when describing style.
vocabulary.example:
The critic's astringent review left the author devastated.
Her astringent wit made her both feared and admired in literary circles.

vocabulary.trait: To work jointly with others, especially in an intellectual endeavor.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Negative (–ve)
Positive when referring to teamwork, negative when referring to treasonous cooperation with an enemy.
vocabulary.example:
The scientists collaborated on groundbreaking research into cancer treatments.
He was accused of collaborating with the occupying forces during the war.
vocabulary.synonyms: cooperate, team up, work together, partner

vocabulary.trait: Having adequate or sufficient ability, knowledge, or skill.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
Positive but modest praise, suggesting adequacy rather than excellence.
vocabulary.example:
The new hire proved to be a competent manager who met all expectations.
She's a competent pianist, though not quite at professional level.

vocabulary.trait: To establish a mutual or reciprocal relationship between things.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Technical term without inherent positive or negative connotations.
vocabulary.example:
The researchers attempted to correlate environmental factors with disease incidence.
We need to correlate the survey responses with demographic data.

vocabulary.trait: To treat or speak of with contempt; to mock or ridicule.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates contempt and disrespect.
vocabulary.example:
Critics derided his early paintings, but they later became highly valued.
The professor derided the student's poorly researched argument.

vocabulary.trait: To issue commands or orders authoritatively; to prescribe.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0)
Often negative when implying authoritarian behavior, neutral in contexts like dictating a letter.
vocabulary.example:
The manager tried to dictate every aspect of the project, frustrating the team.
The attorney dictated notes to her assistant.

vocabulary.trait: Showing good judgment in conduct and speech; prudent and circumspect.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Valued quality indicating trustworthiness and sensitivity.
vocabulary.example:
She was discreet about the confidential information shared in the meeting.
The hotel staff remained discreet about their celebrity guests.

vocabulary.trait: Separated completely from something previously associated with.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve)
When not referring to marital status, often suggests an undesirable disconnection.
vocabulary.example:
His policies seem completely divorced from economic reality.
The theory is divorced from practical application.

vocabulary.trait: Relating to or supporting the view that a society should be led by an elite; believing in one's superiority.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Generally carries negative connotations of snobbery and exclusivity.
vocabulary.example:
The club was criticized for its elitist membership policies.
His elitist attitude alienated many potential supporters.

vocabulary.trait: Demanding accuracy and precision; rigorous and severe in requirements.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve)
Can be positive when indicating high standards, neutral or negative when suggesting excessive demands.
vocabulary.example:
The exacting standards of the competition challenged even the most talented participants.
She was an exacting editor who improved every manuscript she touched.

vocabulary.trait: Utterly confused or bewildered; perplexed.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve)
Suggests a state of confusion that may be temporary or problematic.
vocabulary.example:
The unexpected question left him completely flummoxed during the interview.
She was flummoxed by the complex instructions for assembling the furniture.

vocabulary.trait: Producing good results; productive or profitable.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates success and productivity.
vocabulary.example:
Their fruitful collaboration resulted in several groundbreaking discoveries.
We had a fruitful discussion that resolved many outstanding issues.

vocabulary.trait: Existing from birth; innate or inherited.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Descriptive without inherent positive or negative judgment.
vocabulary.example:
Her inborn talent for music was evident from an early age.
Scientists debate whether certain behaviors are inborn or learned.

vocabulary.trait: A person of wide-ranging knowledge or learning across various subjects.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates impressive intellectual breadth and achievement.
vocabulary.example:
Leonardo da Vinci was a true polymath, excelling in art, science, and engineering.
As a polymath, she contributed to fields ranging from mathematics to literature.
vocabulary.antonyms: specialist, expert in a single field

vocabulary.trait: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily; reserved or uncommunicative.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Can be seen as positive (discreet) or negative (uncommunicative) depending on context.
vocabulary.example:
The reticent scientist rarely spoke about his ongoing research.
She was reticent about her personal life during the interview.

vocabulary.trait: Strict, precise, and exacting; rigorous or severe.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve)
Can be positive when referring to necessary standards, neutral or negative when excessive.
vocabulary.example:
The company implemented stringent security measures after the data breach.
The grant has stringent requirements that many applicants struggle to meet.

vocabulary.trait: Overly willing to obey others; submissive or subordinate.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Generally implies excessive submission or lack of independence.
vocabulary.example:
She refused to take a subservient role in the relationship.
The country's foreign policy became increasingly subservient to its larger neighbor.

vocabulary.trait: Done, made, or acquired by stealth; clandestine or secretive.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0)
Often negative, suggesting secrecy for questionable reasons.
vocabulary.example:
He made a surreptitious glance at his competitor's notes.
The documents were removed from the office in a surreptitious manner.

vocabulary.trait: Tormenting or teasing with the sight or promise of something unobtainable.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
Usually positive, suggesting tempting allure.
vocabulary.example:
The chef presented a tantalizing array of desserts.
The research offers tantalizing clues about ancient civilizations.

vocabulary.trait: Equivalent to something in significance, effect, or value.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Technical term indicating equivalence without inherent judgment.
vocabulary.example:
His silence was tantamount to an admission of guilt.
Cutting the budget would be tantamount to abandoning the project entirely.
vocabulary.synonyms: equivalent, equal, comparable, synonymous, amounting to

vocabulary.trait: A state of mental or physical inactivity or lethargy.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates an undesirable state of sluggishness or inactivity.
vocabulary.example:
The extreme heat induced a state of torpor among the workers.
After the large meal, he fell into a torpor and slept for hours.

vocabulary.trait: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style; sharp, keen, or penetrating.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Suggests effective, forceful expression or analysis.
vocabulary.example:
Her trenchant analysis of the economic crisis impressed the panel.
The book offers a trenchant critique of modern political systems.

vocabulary.trait: Offense or annoyance; resentment.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates displeasure or offense taken.
vocabulary.example:
He took umbrage at the suggestion that his work was derivative.
She expressed umbrage over not being invited to the meeting.

vocabulary.trait: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates valuable flexibility and adaptability.
vocabulary.example:
The versatile actor could perform in comedy, drama, and musical productions.
This versatile software can be used for a wide range of business applications.

vocabulary.trait: Difficult to control or predict because of willful or perverse behavior.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Suggests problematic unpredictability or disobedience.
vocabulary.example:
The wayward teenager frequently ignored her parents' rules.
His wayward approach to business led to unpredictable results.

vocabulary.trait: Make someone feel isolated and estranged
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His rude behavior will alienate his colleagues.
The new policies alienated many long-time customers.

vocabulary.trait: Lack of interest or enthusiasm towards something
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Voter apathy resulted in low turnout for the election.
The teacher was concerned about the students' apathy toward learning.

vocabulary.trait: Appropriate or relevant to the situation
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
His comments were apropos to our discussion.
She made an apropos remark about the economic situation.

vocabulary.trait:
Suitable or appropriate
; Having a tendency toward something
; Quick to learn
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
Her description was apt for the situation.
The child is apt at mathematics.
He is apt to forget important dates.

vocabulary.trait: Conceal or disguise
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When used for protection or privacy
Negative: When used for deception
vocabulary.example:
She tried to cloak her disappointment with a smile.
The government cloaked its true intentions behind diplomatic language.

vocabulary.trait: General agreement among the members of a group
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The committee reached a consensus on the new policy.
There is a growing consensus among scientists about climate change.

vocabulary.trait: Give a false or misleading account of
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The reporter distorted the facts to create a more sensational story.
Mirrors in funhouses distort your reflection.

vocabulary.trait: Growing further apart; disagreeing
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The two teams had divergent strategies for solving the problem.
Their divergent opinions made it difficult to reach an agreement.

vocabulary.trait: Very happy or proud
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She was elated when she received the job offer.
The team was elated after winning the championship.

vocabulary.trait: Capture the attention or to charm
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The musician's performance enchanted the audience.
The children were enchanted by the magician's tricks.

vocabulary.trait: Firmly ingrained and unlikely to change
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The company has entrenched policies that are difficult to change.
Entrenched beliefs can prevent people from considering new ideas.

vocabulary.trait: Foreign, especially in an exciting way
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
They served exotic dishes from around the world.
She collected exotic plants for her garden.

vocabulary.trait: Taking unfair advantage of a person, group, or situation
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The company's exploitative practices harmed both workers and the environment.
Critics called the film exploitative of its subject matter.

vocabulary.trait: Able to be predicted or expected
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The consequences were foreseeable to anyone paying attention.
We have enough supplies for the foreseeable future.

vocabulary.trait: Abandon or give up
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
He forsook his family to pursue his career.
She had to forsake her dream of becoming an athlete after her injury.

vocabulary.trait: Please or satisfy; make content
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
It gratified him to see his students succeed.
Her praise gratified his ego.

vocabulary.trait: Mind or regard with care; pay attention
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
You should heed the warnings about the storm.
The company failed to heed the advice of its consultants.

vocabulary.trait: Having, characterized by, or done with good judgment or sound thinking
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The judge made a judicious decision based on the evidence.
A judicious investment strategy can reduce financial risk.

vocabulary.trait: Clear and easy to understand
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Her explanation was lucid and helpful.
Despite his illness, he remained lucid and aware of his surroundings.

vocabulary.trait: Important with regard to a subject or matter; relevant
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She asked pertinent questions during the interview.
The document contains pertinent information about the case.

vocabulary.trait: Conformity to established standards of good or proper behavior
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She always behaved with propriety at formal events.
The board questioned the propriety of the director's actions.

vocabulary.trait: Brilliantly or impressively clever, exciting, amusing or witty
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The author gave a scintillating performance at the book reading.
Their conversation was scintillating, full of wit and intelligence.

vocabulary.trait: Exaggerated for effect, often sacrificing accuracy
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The tabloid published a sensational account of the celebrity's private life.
The performance was sensational, leaving the audience stunned.

vocabulary.trait:
Experienced, worldly, or cultured
; Advanced or intricate, often in tech
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
She has sophisticated taste in art and music.
The new security system uses sophisticated technology to detect intruders.

vocabulary.trait: Conflict or struggle
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The region has been plagued by political strife for decades.
Their marriage was full of strife and disagreement.

vocabulary.trait: Expressed in a subtle, restrained, or low-key manner
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
Her understated elegance was more impressive than flashy displays.
The film's understated approach to the subject made it more powerful.

vocabulary.trait: Without moral principles
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The unscrupulous businessman defrauded his clients.
She used unscrupulous tactics to eliminate her competition.

vocabulary.trait: Conformity to truth or accuracy
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The veracity of his statement was confirmed by witnesses.
Scientists questioned the veracity of the research findings.

vocabulary.trait: Extremely hostile or malicious; intensely acrimonious
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
He launched a virulent attack on his political opponents.
The disease is caused by a particularly virulent strain of bacteria.

vocabulary.trait: Likely to change unpredictably and quickly (usually for the worse)
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
The stock market has been volatile this month.
His volatile temper made him difficult to work with.

vocabulary.trait: To occur before (something) in time; precede.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The ancient ruins antedate the Roman Empire by several centuries.
The tradition antedates the founding of the country.

vocabulary.trait: To expel from a place, especially as punishment; get rid of.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Generally indicates removal or elimination, often forcefully.
vocabulary.example:
The king banished the disloyal advisor from the kingdom.
She tried to banish the negative thoughts from her mind.
vocabulary.synonyms: exile, expel, deport, cast out, evict

vocabulary.trait: To control or restrain; to show resentment or anger, especially by drawing up the head and chin.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Negative: When indicating resentment or anger.
Neutral: When simply referring to controlling something.
vocabulary.example:
She bridled at his insulting remarks.
The government attempted to bridle inflation through monetary policy.

vocabulary.trait: To obey someone's rules or wishes; meet certain standards.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Generally indicates conformity or adherence.
vocabulary.example:
All businesses must comply with the new safety regulations.
She complied with her doctor's orders to rest.

vocabulary.trait: Disappointed, dispirited, or depressed.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates disappointment or sadness.
vocabulary.example:
The team looked crestfallen after losing the championship game.
He was crestfallen when he heard the bad news.

vocabulary.trait: To restrict or limit; decrease in quantity.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Negative: When limiting something desirable.
Neutral: When limiting something excessive or problematic.
vocabulary.example:
Budget cuts forced the school to curtail its music program.
The company curtailed unnecessary spending to avoid bankruptcy.

vocabulary.trait: To make clear; clarify or shed light on.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates bringing clarity and understanding.
vocabulary.example:
The professor elucidated the complex theory for his students.
Please elucidate how this solution works.

vocabulary.trait: To avoid or escape from, typically in a cunning way; to deflect from giving a clear answer.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Generally implies deception or dishonesty.
vocabulary.example:
The suspect managed to evade the police for months.
The politician evaded answering the reporter's direct questions.

vocabulary.trait: Without skill, ineffective, incompetent; lacking purpose or vitality.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates ineffectiveness or incompetence.
vocabulary.example:
His feckless attempt to repair the car made the problem worse.
The manager criticized the feckless attitude of some team members.

vocabulary.trait: To worsen over time, especially due to neglect; to decay or rot.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates deterioration or worsening.
vocabulary.example:
Their unresolved argument festered for years.
The wound began to fester due to improper care.

vocabulary.trait: Challenging or overthrowing tradition or established beliefs; breaking or destroying images.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve) depending on context
Neutral: When simply describing challenging tradition.
Positive: When innovation or challenging outdated beliefs is valued.
vocabulary.example:
The artist's iconoclastic approach revolutionized modern art.
His iconoclastic views often put him at odds with the establishment.

vocabulary.trait: To imprison or isolate; to enclose within walls.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates confinement or imprisonment.
vocabulary.example:
The princess was immured in the tower for years.
He felt immured in his boring office job.

vocabulary.trait: To create something spontaneously without preparation; to make do with what is available.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing the act itself.
Positive: When creativity and adaptability are highlighted.
vocabulary.example:
The jazz musician improvised a beautiful solo.
When the projector broke, the presenter had to improvise a lecture without slides.
vocabulary.synonyms: extemporize, ad-lib, make up, invent on the spot

vocabulary.trait: To make difficult to accomplish; act as an obstacle; to restrain or prevent.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates restriction or hindrance.
vocabulary.example:
Alcohol can inhibit motor functions.
Her shyness inhibited her from speaking up in meetings.

vocabulary.trait: Not easily understood; mysterious or difficult to interpret.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Describes something difficult to understand without inherent positive or negative value.
vocabulary.example:
The ancient text remained inscrutable despite years of study.
His inscrutable expression gave no hint of his thoughts.

vocabulary.trait: To treat someone as a celebrity or hero; to give excessive attention or praise.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing legitimate admiration.
Negative: When suggesting excessive or undeserved adulation.
vocabulary.example:
The media lionized the young athlete after his Olympic victory.
Some critics argued that the author was unduly lionized despite mediocre work.

vocabulary.trait: Lacking in variety; repetitively dull; tedious due to sameness.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates tedium or lack of variety.
vocabulary.example:
The speaker's monotonous voice put several audience members to sleep.
She found the monotonous routine of her job unbearable.

vocabulary.trait: Strange or unusual; specific or particular to a person, place, or thing.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0)
Can describe uniqueness without inherent judgment.
vocabulary.example:
The house had a peculiar smell that no one could identify.
Each region has its own peculiar customs and traditions.

vocabulary.trait: To consider or plan beforehand; to deliberate in advance.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing careful planning.
Negative: When associated with crimes or harmful actions.
vocabulary.example:
The crime was clearly premeditated, not a spontaneous act.
She premeditated every aspect of the business proposal.
vocabulary.synonyms: plan, scheme, plot, contemplate in advance

vocabulary.trait: Inclined to waste resources or behave extravagantly; recklessly wasteful or immoral.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates wastefulness or extravagance.
vocabulary.example:
The profligate spending of the company led to its bankruptcy.
His profligate lifestyle eventually caught up with him.

vocabulary.trait: To bring back or return to harmony; restore a relationship; to make compatible or consistent.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates resolution of conflict or inconsistency.
vocabulary.example:
The mediator helped reconcile the feuding neighbors.
She couldn't reconcile her beliefs with the new evidence.

vocabulary.trait: To purify or bring to a pure state; to improve in accuracy or excellence; to make more polished.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates improvement or enhancement.
vocabulary.example:
The company refined its manufacturing process to reduce waste.
The author spent months refining her manuscript.

vocabulary.trait: To give up or release a claim, right, or possession; to surrender or let go.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing the act itself.
Negative: When giving up something valuable or desired.
vocabulary.example:
The champion reluctantly relinquished his title after the defeat.
She was forced to relinquish control of the company to the board.
vocabulary.synonyms: surrender, give up, abandon, yield, cede

vocabulary.trait: To meditate or reflect; to ponder over; to think deeply about something.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve) depending on context
Neutral: When simply describing thoughtfulness.
Positive: When deep thought leads to insight.
Can be negative when indicating obsessive overthinking.
vocabulary.example:
She ruminated on the problem for days before finding a solution.
He tends to ruminate on past mistakes instead of moving forward.

vocabulary.trait: Easily scared or startled; timid; difficult to control; unpredictably excitable.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing natural caution.
Negative: When indicating problematic nervousness.
vocabulary.example:
The skittish horse was difficult to train.
Investors became skittish after the market downturn.
vocabulary.synonyms: nervous, jumpy, timid, easily frightened, jittery

vocabulary.trait: More than is necessary or required; excessive; redundant.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve)
Indicates unnecessary excess.
vocabulary.example:
The editor removed all superfluous details from the article.
His superfluous comments only confused the issue further.

vocabulary.trait: Providing a general overview or summary; taking a broad view.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Positive (+ve)
Indicates comprehensive overview without detailed judgment.
vocabulary.example:
The textbook offered a synoptic view of world history.
His synoptic report covered all the major points quickly.

vocabulary.trait: Careful and complete concerning every detail; comprehensive and exhaustive.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates completeness and carefulness.
vocabulary.example:
The detective conducted a thorough investigation of the crime scene.
Her thorough preparation for the exam paid off with a high score.

vocabulary.trait: Showing foresight or imagination; having or marked by vision or foresight.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve)
Indicates innovative thinking and foresight.
vocabulary.example:
The visionary entrepreneur anticipated market trends years in advance.
Her visionary ideas transformed the company.

vocabulary.trait: Expressing opinions or feelings loudly and forcefully; characterized by vehement outcry.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing passionate expression.
Negative: When indicating disruptive or excessive loudness.
vocabulary.example:
The proposal received vociferous opposition from local residents.
He was a vociferous advocate for human rights.

vocabulary.trait: Praise with great approval; enthusiastic approval.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Her novel received widespread acclaim from critics.
The artist's work has earned international acclaim.

vocabulary.trait: Find out or learn with certainty.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The detective worked to ascertain the facts of the case.
We need to ascertain whether the information is accurate.

vocabulary.trait: Confident and direct in claiming one's rights or expressing ideas.
vocabulary.sense:
Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Positive: When confidence is appropriate and respectful.
Neutral: When directness is necessary but may create tension.
vocabulary.example:
She's become more assertive in meetings, making sure her ideas are heard.
Being assertive about your needs is different from being aggressive.

vocabulary.trait: Fake or fraudulent; not genuine.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The email turned out to be a bogus attempt to steal personal information.
The company was selling bogus health supplements.

vocabulary.trait: Causing great disruption or upheaval; catastrophic.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The earthquake had cataclysmic effects on the coastal region.
Their financial decisions led to cataclysmic consequences for the company.

vocabulary.trait: Limit or restrict something narrowly; confine within boundaries.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When setting appropriate boundaries.
Negative: When limitations are excessive or restrictive.
vocabulary.example:
The new regulations circumscribe what businesses can do with customer data.
His freedom was circumscribed by the terms of his parole.

vocabulary.trait: Enhancing or perfecting when combined with something else; completing.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Their skills are complementary, making them an effective team.
The blue and orange colors are complementary and create visual interest.

vocabulary.trait: Causing or likely to provoke disagreement or argument.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Immigration remains a contentious issue in political debates.
The meeting became contentious when discussing budget cuts.

vocabulary.trait: Pretending to be sincere or straightforward; not candid or honest.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His disingenuous apology didn't seem sincere at all.
It's disingenuous to claim ignorance when you were fully informed.

vocabulary.trait: Disclose or reveal information, especially private or sensitive information.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The witness refused to divulge the name of his source.
She was unwilling to divulge personal details about her relationship.

vocabulary.trait: Insisting on one's ideas without being open to others'; asserting opinions in an arrogant manner.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His dogmatic approach to management alienated many employees.
She became increasingly dogmatic in her religious views.

vocabulary.trait: False or mistaken; based on a mistaken belief or faulty reasoning.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His argument relies on fallacious assumptions about economic growth.
The theory was based on fallacious interpretations of the data.

vocabulary.trait: Recklessly daring or careless; taking unnecessary risks.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
It was foolhardy to attempt climbing the mountain during a storm.
His foolhardy investment strategy lost him a fortune.

vocabulary.trait: Obstruct or delay progress; make it difficult for someone to do something.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Bad weather hindered rescue efforts after the hurricane.
Bureaucracy can hinder innovation and quick decision-making.

vocabulary.trait: Weaken or affect negatively; damage or diminish in strength or quality.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Alcohol can impair your judgment and reaction time.
The injury impaired his ability to walk normally.

vocabulary.trait: Challenge the truth or honesty of something; call into question.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Negative: When used as an attack.
Neutral: When legitimately questioning validity.
vocabulary.example:
The lawyer tried to impugn the witness's testimony.
Critics impugned the integrity of the research findings.

vocabulary.trait: Constant or unending, especially of something bad or unpleasant; continuing without pause.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The incessant noise from construction made it impossible to concentrate.
Her incessant complaints were wearing everyone down.

vocabulary.trait: Feeling a tendency or preference towards; disposed or likely to do something.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
She's inclined to agree with your proposal.
I'm not inclined to trust someone I've just met.

vocabulary.trait: Deep-rooted or long-established; having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing a harmless habit.
Negative: When describing bad habits or prejudices.
vocabulary.example:
He's an inveterate traveler who visits at least five countries each year.
She's an inveterate gossip who can't keep a secret.

vocabulary.trait: Reluctant to spend or share; excessively frugal or greedy.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
Despite his wealth, he lived a miserly existence, denying himself basic comforts.
The company's miserly approach to employee benefits led to high turnover.

vocabulary.trait: Clear or obvious; easily recognizable or apparent.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
It was patent to everyone that she was lying.
The solution to the problem was patent once we had all the information.

vocabulary.trait: Irritable or impatient, especially over minor issues; childishly sulky or bad-tempered.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The child gave a petulant response when told to clean his room.
His petulant behavior at the meeting was unprofessional.

vocabulary.trait: Expressing ideas in a concise, meaningful manner; brief but forceful and meaningful.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
Her pithy comments often cut to the heart of complex issues.
The essay was pithy and compelling, making its point in just a few paragraphs.

vocabulary.trait: Flexible or easily influenced; easily bent or shaped.
vocabulary.sense:
Neutral (0) or Negative (–ve) depending on context
Neutral: When describing physical flexibility or adaptability.
Negative: When suggesting someone is too easily manipulated.
vocabulary.example:
Young bamboo is pliant and can be shaped as it grows.
His pliant nature made him susceptible to peer pressure.

vocabulary.trait: Giving the impression that one is morally superior; making a show of being morally better than others.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
His sanctimonious lecture on honesty was ironic given his own dishonest behavior.
She gave a sanctimonious speech about charity while doing little herself.

vocabulary.trait: Based on reason, sense, or judgment; reliable, thorough, or free from defect.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The engineer confirmed that the bridge was sound and safe to cross.
Her sound advice helped me make the right decision.

vocabulary.trait: Compromise, damage, or sully; lose or cause to lose luster.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The scandal tarnished his previously spotless reputation.
Years of neglect had tarnished the once-prestigious award.

vocabulary.trait: Exhibiting little passion or eagerness; lukewarm or halfhearted.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Negative: When enthusiasm is expected.
Neutral: When describing temperature or mild reactions.
vocabulary.example:
The proposal received only tepid support from the committee.
The audience's tepid applause suggested they weren't impressed.

vocabulary.trait: Criticize or scold severely; find fault with someone severely.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The manager upbraided the employee for missing the deadline.
Parents often upbraid children for neglecting their responsibilities.

vocabulary.trait: The state of being irritated or incensed; annoyance or frustration.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
To his vexation, the flight was delayed for the third time.
She couldn't hide her vexation when the computer crashed again.

vocabulary.trait: Assist or encourage, usually in wrongdoing.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
She was charged with abetting the crime by providing a getaway car.
The teacher refused to abet the students' cheating scheme.

vocabulary.trait: Clear; capable of being understood.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve)
vocabulary.example:
The professor's lectures were accessible even to students with no prior knowledge of the subject.
The website has an accessible design that works well for users with disabilities.

vocabulary.trait: Eager to acquire and possess things.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
Generally negative when referring to greed or excessive materialism.
vocabulary.example:
His acquisitive nature led him to collect far more possessions than he could ever use.
The acquisitive corporation continued buying smaller companies to eliminate competition.

vocabulary.trait: Merge or combine two or more things.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The two companies decided to amalgamate their resources to create a stronger business.
The chef amalgamated several cooking styles to create a unique cuisine.

vocabulary.trait: Weaken or lessen in force or thickness.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The walls attenuate the sound from the street.
Her illness had attenuated her strength considerably.

vocabulary.trait: Increase or make larger.
vocabulary.sense: Positive (+ve) or Neutral (0) depending on context
vocabulary.example:
She took evening classes to augment her professional skills.
The company hired additional staff to augment their customer service team.

vocabulary.trait: An intense or definite dislike.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
He has an aversion to spicy food and avoids it completely.
Her aversion to public speaking has limited her career advancement.

vocabulary.trait: Showing indifference or casual cheerfulness.
vocabulary.sense:
Negative (–ve) or Positive (+ve) depending on context
Negative: When describing careless disregard.
Positive: When describing carefree happiness.
vocabulary.example:
She was blithe about the risks involved in the expedition.
The children ran with blithe spirits through the meadow.

vocabulary.trait: The feeling or attitude of regarding someone or something as inferior.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The critic's review was filled with contempt for the amateur production.
She looked at the dishonest politician with contempt.

vocabulary.trait: Move slowly and without purpose.
vocabulary.sense: Negative (–ve)
vocabulary.example:
The children dawdled on their way to school, arriving late.
Don't dawdle when we have so much work to complete before the deadline.

vocabulary.trait: Change the direction or course of something; make someone deviate.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
The goalie managed to deflect the ball away from the goal.
She tried to deflect attention from her mistake by changing the subject.
vocabulary.synonyms: divert, redirect, turn aside, avert, sidetrack

vocabulary.trait: Regard something as being unimportant or incorrect.
vocabulary.sense: Neutral (0)
vocabulary.example:
We shouldn't discount the possibility of unexpected complications.
The committee discounted his testimony as unreliable.
